command.commandDescription: Deletes a buffer or pair of inverters connected back-to-back. This command merges wires after ECO. This command does not modify dont_touch nets if setEcoMode -honorDontTouch is set to true.

commandDescriptionNotes.commandDescriptionNote: The ecoDeleteRepeater command is simultaneous setup/hold and MMMC aware. To make the command simultaneous setup/hold aware, set the global variable set_global timing_enable_simultaneous_setup_hold_mode to true. The simultaneous setup/hold mode can only be used for timing analysis. It cannot be used for any physical implementation steps.

commandParameter.commandParameterDescription: Evaluates the effect on timing, if you delete the specified cell. The values are not applied in the database.

commandParametersNotes.commandParametersNote: You can specify the following using the setEcoMode command: setEcoMode -honorDontUse false to modify instances which have dontUse attribute on cells. setEcoMode -honorDontTouch false to modify instance/nets which are marked dontTouch.

commandExample.commandExampleDescription: The following command deletes the specified buffer, A/inst1
The following command deletes a back-to-back inverter pair containing A/inv1
The following command deletes the instance containing DTMF_INST/ TDSP_CORE_INST/i_10177 and evaluates the effect on timing
The following command deletes instances DTMF_INST/RESULTS_CONV_INST/ FE_PHC845_r1644_2_ and DTMF_INST/RESULTS_CONV_INST/ FE_PHC845_r1643_3_

command.commandSyntax: ecoChangeCell -cell list_of_cells |-upsize | -downsize | -evaluateAll [-bufOrient {R0 | R90 | R180 | R270 | MX | MX90 | MY | MY90}] -inst instNames [-loc {xLoc yLoc}] [-pinMap oldpin1 newpin1 oldpin2 newpin2 ...] [-evaluateOnly | -evaluateAll]
command.commandDescription: Upsizes or downsizes the specified instance based on the available footprint. Cell mapping is also possible as long as the output pins are functionally the same. This command also checks for and observes power domains. This command does not modify dont_touch nets if setEcoMode -honorDontTouch is set to true .

commandDescriptionNotes.commandDescriptionNote: If you use the ecoChangeCell command to modify a ` fixed ' instance, the software issues a warning message. Instead, you can specify the following using the setEcoMode command: setEcoMode -honorFixedStatus false , to modify FIXED instance. setEcoMode -honorDontUse false to modify instances which have dontUse attribute on cells. setEcoMode -honorDontTouch false to modify instance/nets which are marked dontTouch.

The ecoChangeCell command is simultaneous setup/hold and MMMC aware. To make the command simultaneous setup/hold aware, set the global variable set_global timing_enable_simultaneous_setup_hold_mode to true. The simultaneous setup/hold mode can only be used for timing analysis. It cannot be used for any physical implementation steps.
When resizing instances inside multiple-instantiated blocks, the resize would be applied to all instantiations of the block.

You can change a buffer to a pair of inverters using the ecoDeleteRepeater and ecoAddRepeater commands. You can change a buffer to an inverter by first using setEcoMode -LEQCheck false and then using ecoChangeCell. However, please note that it results in the change in logic.

commandParameter.commandParameterSyntax: -bufOrient {R0 | R90 | R180 | R270 | MX | MX90 | MY | MY90}
commandParameter.commandParameterDescription: Specifies the legalized orientation for the instance. You can specify this parameter with the -loc parameter only.

Evaluates the effect on timing for all the cell types available for the new cell. The timing report shows the effects of all the cell types, enabling you to select the best cell for your design. The values are not applied in the database.
Evaluates the effect on timing, if you modify the specified cell. The values are not applied in the database.
Specifies the names of the instances to be changed.
Specifies the legalized location where the instance will be placed.

Upsizes the specified instance with the next available cell in the same footprint unless the specified cell is already of the highest driving strength. Upsizing an instance that drives a large load can improve the driver delay and the transition time at the receivers.

Downsizes the specified instance with the next available cell in the same footprint unless the specified cell is already of the lowest driving strength. Downsizing an instance on the noncritical path can reduce the loading of its driver on the critical path.

Specifies the name of a specific cell(s) to be substituted in the design. The function of the original cell has to match the function of the new cell for all the outputs used by the old cell. The original master cell and the new master cell must have exactly same number of pins.

Specifies the pin mapping for the new cell based on the old cell. This option is required if the new master cell has different pin names than the original cell. The net connected to oldpin1 of the original cell should be connected to newpin1 of the new cell, and so forth.

commandExample.commandExampleDescription: Modifies the specified instance according to the specified cell
Changes to another cell with a different pin name
commandExample.commandExampleSyntax: ecoChangeCell -inst Top_I27 -cell TXOR2X2 -PINMAP A X B Y Y Z

commandExample.commandExampleDescription: Downsizes the specified instance and evaluates timing after you modified the instance

command.commandDescription: Reports information on clocks created with the create_clock and create_generated_clock command. The report includes information about all clock waveforms, clock arrival points, and clock uncertainties. Use the -description , -arrival_points , -uncertainty_table , and the *_table parameters to specify different parts of the report. If one of these options is supplied, only the section that the option corresponds to is reported. If other options are supplied, those sections are also reported. Based on the current setup or hold analysis mode, the following parameters report only one of the late or early tables: -phase_shift_table -total_shift_table -uncertainty_table -adjustment_table -delay_adjustment_table However, in simultaneous (setup and hold) mode both the tables are reported. The report_clocks command only reports constraints with respect to clock waveforms. Use the report_ports -type command for constraints applied to clock pins.

commandParameter.commandParameterDescription: When specified with > , writes the report to the specified file name. If the file already exists, the software overwrites it. When specified with >> , writes the report to the specified file name. If the file already exists, the software concatenates the report to the end of the file. The filename parameter must be the last argument in the list. The filename and -tcl_list parameters are mutually exclusive; you cannot specify them together. Note: To write a compressed report, add the .gz extension to the file name. Default: Report is displayed on standard output without being saved.

Reports two tables that detail the hold and setup cycle adjustments between clock waveforms as set by the set_multicycle_path command. Note: If specific ideal (or generated) clocks are requested with the -clocks clock_name_list option, then only the relationships between those clock signals are reported.

Reports only the clock arrival points. A clock arrival point is the pin where the create_clock or create_generated_clock command has been asserted. Note: This parameter is obsolete and will be removed in a future release.

Requests information on a specific ideal (or generated) clock. If a list is given, only information about those clocks is reported. You can use wildcards in the names. Default : All clocks, except generated clocks, are reported. Use the -generated option to report generated clocks. This parameter is obsolete and will be removed in a future release. Cadence recommends that you specify clock names without the -clocks parameter.

Reports two tables that detail the early and late path delay adjustments between clock waveforms as set by the set_max_delay and set_min_delay commands. Note: If specific ideal (or generated) clocks are requested with the -clocks clock_name_list option, then only the relationships between those clock signals are reported.
Reports only the description of the specified clock waveform(s).

Includes information on generated clocks in the report, such as source and master clock of the generated clock, and other information specified in the create_generated_clock constraints. The report uses the internal clock names created by the system, if you did not specify new clock names while creating these clocks. This parameter is obsolete and will be removed in a future release. The software now reports generated clocks by default.
Reports the existing clock groups.
Reports the inter-clock relationship in tree style format.
Reports the network insertion delays specified on clock waveforms. The values in the table are in min:typ:max format.

Reports the table that details the phase shift between clock waveforms. Based upon the current analysis mode, the table shows the phase shifts either in late or early mode. In case of simultaneous setup hold mode, both the tables are reported for phase shift in late and early mode. Note: If specific ideal (or generated) clocks are requested with the -clocks clock_name_list option, then only the relationships between those clock signals are reported.
Reports the source insertion delays specified on clock waveforms.

Produces the report in Tcl list format instead of a tabular format. This is useful for integrating timing with custom Tcl functions, and also for customizing report generation. The -tcl_list and filename parameters are mutually exclusive; you cannot specify them together.

Based on the current analysis mode, reports one of the tables (late or early mode) that details the total relationship between clock waveforms. In case of simultaneous setup hold mode both the tables are reported. Note: If specific ideal (or generated) clocks are requested with the -clocks clock_name_list option, then only the relationships between those clock signals are reported.

Based on the current analysis mode, reports one of the tables (late mode or early mode) that detail the uncertainty between clock waveforms as specified using the set_clock_uncertainty command. In case of simultaneous setup hold mode both the tables are reported. The tables report only those clock waveforms for which uncertainty has been defined using the set_clock_uncertainty command. Note: If specific ideal (or generated) clocks are requested with the -clocks clock_name_list option, then only the relationships between those clock signals are reported.
Generates a clock report for the specified analysis view only. You can specify this parameter only when the software is in multi-mode multicorner timing analysis mode.

commandExample.commandExampleDescription: The following command displays the default report
The following command displays only the uncertainty information
commandExample.commandExampleSyntax: set_clock_uncertainty 5 CLK_W_1 set_clock_uncertainty 4 -from CLK_W_1 -to CLK_W_4_gen1set_clock_uncertainty 6 -from CLK_W_2 -to CLK_W_4_gen2 report_clocks -uncertainty_table

commandExample.commandExampleOutput: When you specify the report_clocks command, the following phase shift table is displayed: ------------------------------------------------------ Clock To Clock Phase Shift (Late) ------------------------------------------------------ From To L->L L->T T->L T->T ------------------------------------------------------ CLK_W_1 CLK_W_1 60.000 0.000 60.000 60.000 ------------------------------------------------------ ------------------------------------------------------ Clock To Clock Phase Shift (Early) ------------------------------------------------------ From To L->L L->T T->L T->T ------------------------------------------------------ CLK_W_1 CLK_W_1 0.000 -60.000 0.000 0.000 ------------------------------------------------------ In this case, L->L has phase shift 6 which means that the path starts from the leading edge of the first period and ends at the leading edge of the second period. L->T has phase shift 0 which means that the path starts from the leading edge of the first period and ends at the trailing edge of the first period. T->L has phase shift 6 which means that the path starts from the trailing edge of first period and ends at the leading edge of the second period. T->T has phase shift 6 which means that the path starts from the trailing edge of the first period and ends at the trailing edge of the second period. You can use the following command to add uncertainty: set_clock_uncertainty 2 CLK_W_1

commandExample.commandExampleDescription: The phase shift and total shift table values will be different. The following command displays the changed shift values as given below
commandExample.commandExampleOutput:
--------------------------------------------------- Total Clock To Clock Phase Shift Required (Late) --------------------------------------------------- From To L->L L->T T->L T->T --------------------------------------------------- CLK_W_1 CLK_W_1 58.000 -2.000 58.000 58.000 --------------------------------------------------- --------------------------------------------------- Total Clock To Clock Phase Shift Required (Early) --------------------------------------------------- From To L->L L->T T->L T->T --------------------------------------------------- CLK_W_1 CLK_W_1 2.000 -58.000 2.000 2.000 --------------------------------------------------- You can see that the uncertainty is subtracted from the phase shift. Consider the following example path: Path 1: MET Setup Check with Pin u2/CK Endpoint: u2/D (v) checked with leading edge of 'CLK_W_1' Beginpoint: CLK2 (v) triggered by trailing edge of 'CLK_W_2' Path Groups: {CLK_W_1} Other End Arrival Time 0.000 - Setup 0.188 + Phase Shift 15.000 - Uncertainty 2.000 = Required Time 12.812 - Arrival Time 12.463 = Slack Time 0.349 Clock Fall Edge 12.500 = Beginpoint Arrival Time 12.500 ---------------------------------------------------------------------- Load Slew Delay Arrival Time Cell Arc Pin
---------------------------------------------------------------------- 0.034 0.003 12.500 CLK2 v CLK2 0.003 0.003 -0.037 12.463 BUF A v -> Y v u10999/Y 0.003 0.003 0.000 12.463 DFF D v u2/D ---------------------------------------------------------------------- Here the begin point div_2_clk to end point std_clk shows a phase shift value of 15.00. This means that if a path starts from the falling edge of CLK_W_2 , and ends at the rising edge of CLK_W_1 , the phase shift is 15.00. In other words, when the timing (setup time) is reported, the required time at the end point begins with 15.00 (in addition to adjustments like setup time, time borrowing, uncertainty, etc). However, the arrival time of this path starts at 12.500.

commandExample.commandExampleDescription: When the software is in multi-mode multi-corner timing analysis mode, the software reports the clock information for each active analysis view
Specify the -view parameter to generate clock information for a specific analysis view only
The report_clocks command output displays a column showing active or inactive clocks in the design

command.commandSyntax: alignObject [-help] -side {right | left | center | top | bottom | middle} [-referToFirst] [-mix]
command.commandDescription: Aligns objects (instances, modules, or blockages) vertically or horizontally in the floorplan. Use this command after selecting two or more objects in the design display area.

commandParameter.commandParameterDescription: Outputs a brief description that includes the type and default information for each alignObject parameter. For a detailed description of the command and all of its parameters, use the man command: man alignObject
Considers all the selected objects together while aligning them.
Specifies a reference object highlighted in the design display area. If you specify this option, the first selected object is the reference object.

Specifies the vertical and horizontal alignment for the selected objects. Choose one of the following: right : Specifies vertical right alignment. left : Specifies vertical left alignment. center : Specifies vertical center alignment. top : Specifies horizontal top alignment. bottom : Specifies horizontal bottom alignment. middle : Specifies horizontal middle alignment. Default : left

commandExample.commandExampleDescription: The following command aligns highlighted objects vertically to the left

command.commandDescription: Analyzes the floorplan, and reports basic design information. To report wire length, congestion, and timing information in addition to basic design information, specify the -congestion and -timing parameters. The analyzeFloorplan command can be used with floorplans generated by Automatic Floorplan Synthesis, generated manually, or generated by a third-party tool. To use the analyzeFloorplan command, the following information must exist in the design: Verilog netlist Physical library (LEF) file Timing library (.lib) file SDC constraint (.sdc) file Additionally, macros in the floorplan must be marked FIXED before running analyzeFloorplan.

commandDescriptionNotes.commandDescriptionNote: For designs having flex models, when the -effort parameter of the set_proto_mode command is set to high, the -congestion and -timing parameters of the analyzeFloorplan command are enabled by default. As a result, wire length and congestion, in addition to the timing information is reported.

commandParameter.commandParameterDescription: Outputs a brief description that includes type and default information for each analyzeFloorplan parameter. For a detailed description of the command and all of its parameters, use the man command: man analyzeFloorplan.
Analyzes congestion for a prototyping design with legal placement.

Specifies the effort level to use for analysis. The -effort parameter allows you to choose between analysis accuracy and run time levels. low : Provides cluster mode placement (non-timing driven). This results in low analysis accuracy, but a fast run time. medium : Provides timing driven floorplan mode placement. This results in medium analysis accuracy and run time. high : Provides timing driven default placement ( placeDesign ). This results in good analysis accuracy, but a longer run time. Default : medium
Analyzes floorplan for a prototyping design with quick placement.
Invokes timing driven Trial Route incrementally.
Enables pre-place optimization during the placement run.

Saves the report to the specified output file. If you do not specify this parameter, the software saves the report to a file named analyzeFP.rpt in addition to showing it in the EDI System command window.
Analyzes timing and reports the total negative slack and worst negative slack for register-to-register paths.
Invokes timing driven Trial Route for prototyping design.

commandExample.commandExampleDescription: The following command analyzes the floorplan and reports basic information on the design
commandExample.commandExampleOutput: The software generates the following report: ###################################################################################### # Generated by: Cadence Encounter 10.11-e004_1 # OS: Linux i686(Host ID icdlnx08s) # Generated on: Mon Oct 11 15:29:06 2010 # Design: dtmf_chip # Command: analyzeFloorplan ###################################################################################### ************************* Analyze Floorplan ****************************************** Die Area(um^2) : 2214144.000000 Core Area(um^2) : 735512.054400 Chip Density (Counting Std Cells and MACROs and IOs): 75.091% Core Density (Counting Std Cells and MACROs) : 65.841% Average utilization : 40.177% Number of instance(s) : 7761 Number of Macro(s) : 40 Number of IO Pin(s) : 57 Number of Power Domain(s) : 1 ************************* Estimation Results ***************************************** **************************************************************************************

commandExample.commandExampleDescription: The following command analyzes the floorplan and reports total wire length, and horizontal and vertical congestion information, in addition to the basic design information
commandExample.commandExampleOutput: The software generates the following report: ###################################################################################### # Generated by: Cadence Encounter 10.11-e004_1 # OS: Linux i686(Host ID icdlnx08s) # Generated on: Mon Oct 11 15:29:06 2010 # Design: dtmf_chip # Command: analyzeFloorplan ###################################################################################### ************************* Analyze Floorplan ****************************************** Die Area(um^2) : 2214144.000000 Core Area(um^2) : 735512.054400 Chip Density (Counting Std Cells and MACROs and IOs): 75.091% Core Density (Counting Std Cells and MACROs) : 65.841% Average utilization : 40.177% Number of instance(s) : 7761 Number of Macro(s) : 40 Number of IO Pin(s) : 57 Number of Power Domain(s) : 1 ************************* Estimation Results ***************************************** Total Wire length. : 3.8294e+05 Congestion (H). : 6.582% Congestion (V). : 8.524% **************************************************************************************

command.commandRelatedTopics: " Creating An Initial Floorplan Using Automatic Floorplan Synthesis " chapter of the EDI System User Guide Analyzing the Floorplan
